title: Vert.x-http: response body of HTTP status 500 should be human-readable by default
body:
### Description

Currently, when a critical (unhandled) error occurs in a REST endpoint, we generate a default response with HTTP status 500 and an HTML webpage describing the error. This is done in `QuarkusErrorHandler`.

While I doubt this matters in production, it can be really annoying when developing, as you perform an HTTP request through `curl`, and you get dozens of lines of HTML in response, right in your terminal.

If your request includes an `Accept: application/json` header, you will get JSON in the response; however, by default, you will get HTML.

### Implementation ideas

**At least in test/dev mode**, we could change the default content type of the response. When an error happens:

* If there is an `Accept` header mentioning `text/html`, `application/xhtml+xml` or `application/xml`, we return HTML.
* If there is an `Accept` header mentioning `application/json`, we return JSON.
* If there isn't any `Accept` header, or if it doesn't mention any supported content-type, we default to some human-readable format. Maybe `application/json`, or maybe just `text/plain`.

My reasoning: all clients that could potentially render HTML (browsers) will probably send an `Accept: text/html` header. 
So if we don't find one, it's probably a human directly requesting something. Or a badly configured REST client, but in that case getting JSON or plain text won't be much worse to get plain text than HTML.
